title: 109_s2205
content: The Act is titled the "Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal Land Conveyance Act of 2006". It pertains to the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal. The Blunt Reservoir feature and Pierre Canal feature are defined in the Act as part of the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin program. The Commission refers to the Commission of Schools and Public Lands of the State. Nonpreferential lease parcels are land parcels purchased by the Secretary for use with the Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal features. The Pierre Canal feature is part of the Oahe Unit, James Division, authorized by the Act of August 3, 1968. A preferential leaseholder is someone who held a lease on a preferential lease parcel as of January 1, 2001. A preferential lease parcel is a land parcel purchased by the Secretary for use in connection with certain features. The term "preferential lease parcel" refers to land purchased by the Secretary for use in connection with specific reservoir features and listed on the Bureau of Reclamation's 2001 lease roster. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, and "State" refers to South Dakota or its successor. An "unleased parcel" is land purchased by the Secretary for future use. The State of South Dakota, including a successor, is defined as "State." An "unleased parcel" is land bought by the Secretary for the Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal features and not currently leased. The Blunt Reservoir feature is deauthorized, and the State may accept ownership of parts of it and the Pierre Canal feature with liabilities post-conveyance. The State of South Dakota may accept ownership of certain parts of the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal features with liabilities post-conveyance. The State will also be responsible for any outstanding obligations related to the ownership, operation, or maintenance of these features. The Commission will act as the agent for the Secretary in administering the purchase option for preferential leaseholders. Any outstanding obligations will be binding upon the State. The State of South Dakota may accept ownership of certain parts of the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal features with liabilities post-conveyance. Any outstanding obligations related to ownership, operation, or maintenance will be binding upon the State and preferential leaseholders. Conveyances to the State or preferential leaseholders are subject to reserved oil, gas, mineral rights, permits, licenses, leases, and rights-of-way held by third parties. The State of South Dakota may accept ownership of certain parts of the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal features with liabilities post-conveyance. Conveyances to the State or preferential leaseholders are subject to reserved rights held by third parties. A preferential leaseholder has an option to purchase the preferential lease parcel. A preferential leaseholder has the option to purchase the preferential lease parcel from the Secretary or the Commission. The terms of purchase include a cash payment equal to a specified amount. The preferential leaseholder can purchase the preferential lease parcel by paying the determined value minus ten percent. The preferential leaseholder can purchase the parcel with 10 percent down and the rest paid over 30 years at 3 percent interest. For parcels under $10,000, the purchase must be made in cash. The leaseholder has 5 years to exercise the purchase option. Until then, they can continue leasing the parcel under the same terms. The preferential leaseholder can continue leasing the parcel under the same terms until a specified date. The value of the lease parcel is determined by its fair market value for agricultural purposes, less 25 percent, as per an independent appraisal. The Act allows preferential leaseholders to purchase land at fair market value. Disputes on property value are resolved according to federal regulations. If a leaseholder fails to buy the parcel, it may be offered to the South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks for wildlife habitat mitigation. The State of South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks will use conveyed land for wildlife habitat mitigation due to the Pick-Sloan project development. Proceeds from land sales will fund a trust to pay county taxes on acquired lands. Nonpreferential lease parcels will be conveyed to the state within a year. The Secretary will offer to convey nonpreferential lease parcels and unleased parcels of the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal to the South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks for wildlife habitat mitigation within a year of the enactment of the Act. The South Dakota Commission of Schools and Public Lands may allow land exchanges for nonpreferential lease parcels and unleased parcels at Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal with the concurrence of the South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks. The priority for exchanges will be granted in a specific order. The right to exchange nonpreferential lease parcels or unleased parcels is granted in a specific order of priority. This includes exchanges with current lessees and adjoining landowners. A perpetual easement for water conveyance structures is reserved by the United States as a condition of the land exchange involving the Pierre Canal feature. The United States grants an easement for a pipeline or water conveyance structure over the Pierre Canal. The US is released from liability for damages related to the conveyed parcel, except for acts of negligence. This does not add to existing liability under the Federal Tort Claims Act. The Secretary must continue leasing preferential and nonpreferential lease parcels until conveyance, with no additional liability under the Federal Tort Claims Act. Legal descriptions of all parcels must be provided to the State within 180 days of enactment. The Secretary must provide legal descriptions of all preferential and nonpreferential lease parcels to the State within 180 days. Additionally, archeological collections from specific features must be transferred to the South Dakota State Historical Society. $750,000 is authorized for expenses incurred in implementing the Act. Authorization of Appropriations: $750,000 is authorized to reimburse the Secretary, Commission, and State Department of Game, Fish, and Parks for expenses incurred in implementing the Act, not to exceed 10 percent of the cost of each transaction conducted under the Act.
